title: How to get over ghosting from a VC 👻👻👻
html:

How to get over ghosting from a VC 👻👻👻

Rica Elysee
Apr 2

The past two years have been filled with interesting relationships for me. I think the most interesting ones have been with VC and Angels. Coming into the fundraising process I think it is common that founders blame themselves for the lack of contact when a VC or Angel disappears. In the new age where ignoring people is ending relationships or just saying no I thought this would be the best topic to dive into with Dr. Loretta Brady this week. How do we know when it is happening, how to get over it or closure. Cheers to being healthy even when people are ghosting you.

How do you deal with self blame?

A key to dealing with self blame is to think like a filmaker: consider the situation from the perspective of the camera and now think about what isn’t in the frame: this is called perspective taking. Taking perspective can help us identify multiple explanations for any given outcome: while we want to be able to take advantage of our wins we also want to be able to recognize we can’t control everything. Of course there are times when perspective and reflection reveal that in fact we did something that got in the way of what we (thought) we wanted. Maybe that connection isn’t what you need or where you are right now. Maybe it isn’t ghosting, but a simple open door. It’s also possibly simply a passive aggressive mental mindfuck (seriously) so we can’t always sweat it. And if you do know you messed up something take stock, make ammends if it’s appropriate to do so, but at least spend some time understanding what about the situation set up those actions and outcome. Guilt can be a reminder to us of why our voice and integrity are some vital in keeping ourselves balenced. And shame can be a reminder that we care about how others see us. When we know better, we can do better as Dr. Angelou said. And frutration can be a clue that communication needs to improve along with autonomy and transparency. These are ultimately relationships that require trust and sometimes our negative feelings are signals to how we should be navigating in our relational worlds, especially ones with money and reputation involved.

Are there legitimate signs that you are being ghosted?

If you requested a time sensitive response on a matter of mutual importance and urgency to you both and no such reply came, and no apology followed after the previously established response period, I would presume someone has moved away from the conversation. If after multiple outreach on more than one topic you have not received a response then that seems pretty clear, especially if you know from other means they are alive and well! At the same time, the concept of “ghosting” may be broad and not entirely evenly understood across people or generations. The ecosystem has all sorts of backgrounds and expectations operating within itself, which means your idea of response etiquette and conflict management may be very different from someone else's, and this difference can mean the difference between you thinking you were ghosted and them getting sidetracked or overscheduled in multiple fronts. There is an adage that we never know what someone is going through, and I find that helpful when opportunities or collaborations fizzle out. It’s part of the refinement process though if we let it be!

How do you deal with the lack of closure when being ignored?

If you feel a real lingering of negative emotion about a failed connection I would reflect in writing or some creative way on what emotions are happening and what is brought up from prior experiences or concerns. Often we have current events tapping into feelings of inadequacy, panic, or distress from earlier times. “Understanding that when X occurs I tend to percieve Y and feel Z so I should remember next time to A” can be a thought that helps us tease apart the various forces at play that led to the outcome.

What tips would you give to investors to end the loop with founders?

Some people can be diplomatic and generous and some people are blunt and to the point. I think both can work but the key is really about expectation management. From the beginning you can help a founder, who may be naive to process, understand what various investor styles look like. You can offer to intro them to someone with a different style (not just portfolio). and you can help them know that you typically take x amount of time for each phase of discernment and review. If you are an investor and you know that you simply walk away from exchanges when you are not interested it would help immensly if you made that clear from the start (or better yet, were a little more relational!). If you are an investor who is done with an interaction I would say simply send a kind email indicating the likelihood of success but the conclusion that you won’t be a part of that at the present time. If there are specific milestones or other things you are looking for to reconsider be clear about that too, and if there is a time specfic reason then share what you are comfortable sharing about it, because being an entrepreneur is exhausting and the doubts and emotional work of navigating these issues is an invisible tax not enough of us are talking about. We can be efficient and compassionate, with ourselves and others.

How should you build the bridge and get over being ghosted?

As you play the role of filmmaker you have identified alternate explanations for what happened. Spend time with those ideas. You can also simply work to accept that the ghosting happened and acknowledge that it feels bad. Sometimes simply allowing ourselves to experience strong negative emotion is enough to help us loosen our load. We must ride the wave of the emotional parts of being a founder because the end game can’t just be about money or contacts or winning. If you are not founding for a purpose beyond yourself these hurtful events will not be tolerable.

Is it a good idea to delete the messages associated with being ghosted?

If you know you tend to ruminate on things, and having them handy makes you tepted to review and beat yourself up, then by all means either archive them or delete them. If there is any part of you that thinks parts of messages were inappropriate or crossed a line you hold you may want to preserve them for a time when you feel you can address that issue. Of course if you shared private details of anything that might be in a NDA or business documents you may wish to consult with your attorney about how best to preserve the information but again, maybe not within easy “scroll”. I think that unless there is a really traumatic connection with the individual that preserving their contact information is wise. The world is small, so remember that even when we think we’ve moved out of an orbit, life has a funny way of pulling folks back in.

How do you get closure for yourself without involving the other party?

You just do. We are the emotions we have, we are them in that we interpret events and sensations and assign them meaning. By understanding that we can’t controll anything, and can’t control anyone, we can find compassion for both ourselves and others. Imperfection is liberating in that when we can accept it in ourselves we can release how others treat us. Now, this isn’t to say that you can’t do things to help yourself do that! Rituals are ways we mark important transitions in our lives. We have ones that are cultural, spiritual, academic. If you are feeling stuck in an interaction that has frozen find a way to release it through a ritual. Maybe you write it on sand and let a wave wash it away, maybe you burn a slip of paper where you wrote out the issue and let it go in a brief moment. Enjoying something that is engaging and creative can help too.

Hope you enjoyed this week’s post. Have questions for Dr. Loretta Brady? Drop her a message HERE

  • Startup
  • Mental Health
  • Ghosting

  • Rica Elysee

    Medium member since Nov 2018

    Founder & CEO of @BeautyLynk and Co-Founder of @atthetablehq

  • Unfiltered: Startup Mental Health

    Blog series about mental health in the startup world with Dr. Loretta Brady and Rica Elysee.
